question: 3 (b)
sols_html:
As in the hint, let \(u = \sqrt{x}\) so that \(du = \frac{dx}{2\sqrt{x}} = \frac{dx}{2u}\). This gives

\(\int \cos\sqrt{x} \, dx = \int 2u\cos(u)\, du\)

To solve this last integral, we use integration by parts. Let

\[\begin{aligned} w = u \quad&\quad v = \sin(u) \\ dw = du \quad & \quad dv = \cos(u)du\end{aligned}\]

Then, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int 2u\cos(u)\, du &= 2\int u\cos(u)\, du\\ &= 2u\sin(u) - 2\int\sin(u)\, du\\ &= 2u\sin(u) + 2\cos(u)\end{aligned}\]

and hence

\[\begin{aligned} \int\cos(\sqrt{x})\, dx &= \int 2u\cos(u)\, du = 2u\sin(u) + 2\cos(u) \\ &= 2\sqrt{x}\sin(\sqrt{x}) + 2\cos(\sqrt{x})\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
As in the hint, let <math> u = \sqrt{x} </math> so that <math> du = \frac{dx}{2\sqrt{x}} = \frac{dx}{2u} </math>. This gives

<math>
\int \cos\sqrt{x} \, dx = \int 2u\cos(u)\, du
</math>

To solve this last integral, we use integration by parts. Let

<math>
\begin{align}
w = u \quad&\quad v = \sin(u) \\
dw = du \quad & \quad dv = \cos(u)du
\end{align}
</math>

Then, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
\int 2u\cos(u)\, du &= 2\int u\cos(u)\, du\\
&= 2u\sin(u) - 2\int\sin(u)\, du\\
&= 2u\sin(u) + 2\cos(u)
\end{align}
</math> 

and hence

<math>
\begin{align}
\int\cos(\sqrt{x})\, dx &= \int 2u\cos(u)\, du = 2u\sin(u) + 2\cos(u) \\
&= 2\sqrt{x}\sin(\sqrt{x}) + 2\cos(\sqrt{x})
\end{align}
</math>
